See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from six.moves.urllib import parse as urlparse def get_collection_links(request, items): """Retrieve 'next' link, if applicable.""" links = [] try: limit = int(request.params.get("limit") or 0) except ValueError: limit = 0 if limit > 0 and limit == len(items): last_item = items[-1] last_item_id = last_item["id"] links.append({ "rel": "next", "href": _get_next_link(request, last_item_id) }) return links def _get_next_link(request, marker): """Return href string with proper limit and marker params.""" params = request.params.copy() params['marker'] = marker return "%s?%s" % (request.path_url, urlparse.urlencode(params))

commit_message:
QoS service plugin stub

This patch introduces the QoS service plugin which implements
a stub of the API extension.

This is patch is a basic step to be able to create an experimental
job enabling this service so we can do api tests.

Change-Id: Ib583e98c232ca628ba2a4bd48527eb84584c6212

neutron.api.v2 import base #from neutron.common import constants as const #from neutron.common import exceptions as nexception from neutron import manager #from neutron.openstack.common import uuidutils VALID_RULE_TYPES = ['bandwidth_limiting'] # Attribute Map QOS_RULE_COMMON_FIELDS = { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True}, 'qos_policy_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'is_visible': True, 'required_by_policy': True}, 'type': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'qos_policies': { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'required_by_policy': True, 'is_visible': True}}, 'qos_bandwidthlimit_rule': dict(QOS_RULE_COMMON_FIELDS, **{'max_kbps': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'default': None, 'validate': {'type:integer', None}}, 'max_burst_kbps': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'default': 0, 'validate': {'type:integer', None}}})} QOS = "qos_policies" EXTENDED_ATTRIBUTES_2_0 = { 'ports': {QOS: {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'default': None, 'validate': {'type:uuid_or_none': None}}}, 'networks': {QOS: {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'default': None, 'validate': {'type:uuid_or_none': None}}}} class Qos(extensions.ExtensionDescriptor): """Security group extension.""" @classmethod def get_name(cls): return "qos" @classmethod def get_alias(cls): return "qos" @classmethod def get_description(cls): return "The Quality of Service extension." @classmethod def get_namespace(cls): # todo return "http://docs.openstack.org/ext/qos/api/v2.0" @classmethod def get_updated(cls): return "2015-06-08T10:00:00-00:00" @classmethod def get_resources(cls): """Returns Ext Resources.""" my_plurals = [(key, key[:-1]) for key in RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.keys()] attr.PLURALS.update(dict(my_plurals)) exts = [] plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_plugin() for resource_name in ['security_group', 'security_group_rule']: collection_name = resource_name.replace('_', '-') + "s" params = RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.get(resource_name + "s", dict()) controller = base.create_resource(collection_name, resource_name, plugin, params, allow_bulk=True, allow_pagination=True, allow_sorting=True) ex = extensions.ResourceExtension(collection_name, controller, attr_map=params) exts.append(ex) return exts def get_extended_resources(self, version): if version == "2.0": return dict(EXTENDED_ATTRIBUTES_2_0.items() + RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.items()) else: return {}

commit_message:
Status_reason, stats and created_time are overwritten by mistake

When creating a node, though status_reason, status,and created_time
are configured in set_status(), but they are overwritten by
self.store(context).

Change-Id: If7d4a849d6e587504a118ae085dfebef4ee6bcb8

commit_message:
Unify input parameter definition in Senlin openstack drivers

This patch tried to unify the input parameter definition in all
Senlin openstack drivers.

Note: keystone_v3 driver will be handled in another patch since
some interfaces implementation need revision.

commit_message:
Test case for cluster_policies API

This patch adds test cases for cluster_policies API.

Change-Id: I0879d03bcae0e9c3bfb664d8a02ffc702089b0bb
Closes-Bug: 1469528
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/47/196447/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock import six from senlin.api.middleware import fault from senlin.api.openstack.v1 import cluster_policies as cp_mod from senlin.common import exception as senlin_exc from senlin.common import policy from senlin.rpc import client as rpc_client from senlin.tests.apiv1 import shared from senlin.tests.common import base @mock.patch.object(policy, 'enforce') class ClusterPolicyControllerTest(shared.ControllerTest, base.SenlinTestCase): '''Tests the API class which acts as the WSGI controller.''' def setUp(self): super(ClusterPolicyControllerTest, self).setUp() # Create WSGI controller instance class DummyConfig(object): bind_port = 8778 cfgopts = DummyConfig() self.controller = cp_mod.ClusterPolicyController(options=cfgopts) def test_cluster_policy_index(self, mock_enforce): self._mock_enforce_setup(mock_enforce, 'index', True) cid = 'test_cluster' req = self._get('/cluster_policies/%s' % cid) engine_resp = [ { 'id': 'fake_id', 'cluster_id': 'fake cluster id', 'policy_id': 'fake policy id', 'enabled': True, 'cooldown': 60, 'level': 30, 'priority': 40, 'data': {}, 'cluster_name': 'test_cluster', 'policy_name': 'test_policy', 'policy_type': 'ScalingPolicy', } ] mock_call = self.patchobject(rpc_client.EngineClient, 'call', return_value=engine_resp) result = self.controller.index(req, tenant_id=self.project, cluster_id=cid) default_args = {'sort_keys': None, 'sort_dir': None, 'filters': None, 'identity': cid} mock_call.assert_called_with(req.context, ('cluster_policy_list', default_args)) expected = {'cluster_policies': engine_resp} self.assertEqual(expected, result) @mock.patch.object(rpc_client.EngineClient, 'call') def test_cluster_policy_index_whitelists_params(self, mock_call, mock_enforce): self._mock_enforce_setup(mock_enforce, 'index', True) cid = 'FAKE_CLUSTER' params = { 'sort_keys': 'fake sort keys', 'sort_dir': 'fake sort dir', 'filters': None, 'balrog': 'you shall not pass!' } req = self._get('/cluster_policies/%s' % cid, params=params) mock_call.return_value = [] self.controller.index(req, tenant_id=self.project, cluster_id=cid) rpc_call_args, _ = mock_call.call_args engine_args = rpc_call_args[1][1] self.assertEqual(4, len(engine_args)) self.assertIn('sort_keys', engine_args) self.assertIn('sort_dir', engine_args) self.assertIn('filters', engine_args) self.assertNotIn('balrog', engine_args) @mock.patch.object(rpc_client.EngineClient, 'call') def test_cluster_policy_index_whitelist_filter_params(self, mock_call, mock_enforce): self._mock_enforce_setup(mock_enforce, 'index', True) cid = 'FAKE_CLUSTER' params = { 'priority': 20, 'level': 50, 'balrog': 'you shall not pass!' } req = self._get('/cluster_policies/%s' % cid, params=params) mock_call.return_value = [] self.controller.index(req, tenant_id=self.project, cluster_id=cid) rpc_call_args, _ = mock_call.call_args engine_args = rpc_call_args[1][1] self.assertIn('filters', engine_args) filters = engine_args['filters'] self.assertEqual(2, len(filters)) self.assertIn('priority', filters) self.assertIn('level', filters) self.assertNotIn('balrog', filters) def test_cluster_policy_index_denied_policy(self, mock_enforce): self._mock_enforce_setup(mock_enforce, 'index', False) cid = 'FAKE_CLUSTER' req = self._get('/cluster_policy/%s' % cid) resp = shared.request_with_middleware(fault.FaultWrapper, self.controller.index, req, tenant_id=self.project, cluster_id=cid) self.assertEqual(403, resp.status_int) self.assertIn('403 Forbidden', six.text_type(resp)) def test_cluster_policy_get_success(self, mock_enforce): self._mock_enforce_setup(mock_enforce, 'get', True) cid = 'FAKE_CLUSTER' pid = 'FAKE_POLICY' req = self._get('/cluster_policies/%(cid)s/%(pid)s' '' % {'cid': cid, 'pid': pid}) engine_resp = { 'id': 'fake_id', 'cluster_id': cid, 'policy_id': pid, 'enabled': True, 'cooldown': 60, 'level': 30, 'priority': 40, 'data': {}, 'cluster_name': 'test_cluster', 'policy_name': 'test_policy', 'policy_type': 'ScalingPolicy', } mock_call = self.patchobject(rpc_client.EngineClient, 'call', return_value=engine_resp) response = self.controller.get(req, tenant_id=self.project, cluster_id=cid, policy_id=pid) mock_call.assert_called_once_with( req.context, ('cluster_policy_get', {'identity': cid, 'policy_id': pid})) self.assertEqual({'cluster_policy': engine_resp}, response) def test_cluster_policy_get_not_found(self, mock_enforce): self._mock_enforce_setup(mock_enforce, 'get', True) cid = 'FAKE_CLUSTER' pid = 'FAKE_POLICY' req = self._get('/cluster_policies/%(cid)s/%(pid)s' '' % {'cid': cid, 'pid': pid}) error = senlin_exc.PolicyBindingNotFound(policy=pid, identity=cid) mock_call = self.patchobject(rpc_client.EngineClient, 'call') mock_call.side_effect = shared.to_remote_error(error) resp = shared.request_with_middleware(fault.FaultWrapper, self.controller.get, req, tenant_id=self.project, cluster_id=cid, policy_id=pid) self.assertEqual(404, resp.json['code']) self.assertEqual('PolicyBindingNotFound', resp.json['error']['type']) def test_action_get_denied_policy(self, mock_enforce): self._mock_enforce_setup(mock_enforce, 'get', False) cid = 'FAKE_CLUSTER' pid = 'FAKE_POLICY' req = self._get('/cluster_policies/%(cid)s/%(pid)s' '' % {'cid': cid, 'pid': pid}) resp = shared.request_with_middleware(fault.FaultWrapper, self.controller.get, req, tenant_id=self.project, cluster_id=cid, policy_id=pid) self.assertEqual(403, resp.status_int) self.assertIn('403 Forbidden', six.text_type(resp))

subject: improve api_version.matches
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-03 00:48:23.000000000', 'files': ['nova/api/openstack/api_version_request.py', 'nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/test_api_version_request.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b1c06b1cb9131cd0e0f3083902302e945c902e27', 'message': 'improve api_version.matches

This is no back-compat break improvement on api version object. The old
matches() only accept APIVersionRequest. As a result, the codes might
become a little bloated, like:

    req_version >= api_version_request.APIVersionRequest("2.3")

This patch makes:

    req_version.matches(min_version="2.3")

or
    req_version.matches("2.1", "2.5")

Change-Id: Ibf02666c63f65f79dcff46b1808d46c104b99c27
'}]
commit_message:
improve api_version.matches

This is no back-compat break improvement on api version object. The old
matches() only accept APIVersionRequest. As a result, the codes might
become a little bloated, like:

    req_version >= api_version_request.APIVersionRequest("2.3")

This patch makes:

    req_version.matches(min_version="2.3")

or
    req_version.matches("2.1", "2.5")

Change-Id: Ibf02666c63f65f79dcff46b1808d46c104b99c27
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/25/170325/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertTrue(v1.matches("1.5", "2.5")) self.assertTrue(v1.matches("1.5", "2.0")) self.assertTrue(v1.matches("2.0", "2.5")) self.assertTrue(v1.matches("2.0", "2.5")) self.assertTrue(v1.matches(max_version="2.5")) self.assertTrue(v1.matches(min_version="1.5")) self.assertFalse(v1.matches("2.1", "2.5"))

subject: Use "RegionOne" as default region
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-14 04:07:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/7b9cffd5a87281f70f2add68f7207f413bee0432', 'message': 'Use "RegionOne" as default region

The string "RegionOne" is more standard as a word rather than
"regionOne". More potential installers, such as devstack, would like
to choose a more standard word by default.

commit_message:
Use "RegionOne" as default region

There is a history in this: devstack create region RegionOne and
keystone doesn't block request of service creataion with region
regionOne then services with regionOne (default region from
keystoneclient) can't communicate with ones created with devstack.

Replacing "regionOne" with "RegionOne" in keystoneclient is a health
change to be little more friendly with devstack and a quick fix for
the issue above.

Related-Bug: #1400589
Change-Id: I3e5c2e78e0e790a6cbf31ba058081e470aa4acd6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/65/173165/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: help='Endpoint region.', default='RegionOne')

commit_message:
Fix gate: move test case to avoid latest fixtures

fixtures 1.3.0 breaks some of our unit tests for an as-yet unknown
reason. This is a workaround that moves the problematic test cases to
no fixtures context, which has been done in this patch. So there are
two class handle different sets of cases. The one with many test
fixtures verifies comlicated _get_from_manage and wait_for_delete. The
one with no test fixtures verifies get_from_manage functionality
itself.

This also temporarily disables the coverage test in order to pass gate

Co-Authored-By: Chris St. Pierre <cstpierr@cisco.com>
Change-Id: Icbf358f3a08488dbb9e0c81c66cea036057caa36
Closes-Bug: #1469644

commit_message:
Replace 'manage_password' with 'replace_password' for keystone_user

We've introduced new option 'manage_password' for keystone_user in
our fork of keystone module. But while submitting the same
functionality to the upstream this option was changed to 'replace_password'.

Upstream change: Ib61128556fed816916af944ed7576e916081da07
Closes-bug: #1446117

Change-Id: I3024bfc81de744af908431ec8028d83ff921c54c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/00/196100/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: replace_password => 'False',

commit_message:
keystoneclient: require at least >= 1.2.0 for stable/kilo

Previous versions of the client capped version of oslo.serialization to
<=1.2.0, which is incompatible with existing oslo.serialization
requirements for the branch (>=1.4.0).

It results in the following failure during a grenade run for the branch:

pkg_resources.ContextualVersionConflict: (oslo.serialization 1.4.0
(/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages),
Requirement.parse('oslo.serialization<=1.2.0,>=1.0.0'),
set(['python-keystoneclient']))

Change-Id: I961cc2c5b7b43ce2298b72ec4a0d105d11283983
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/87/196887/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: python-keystoneclient>=1.2.0,<1.4.0

commit_message:
Use sets to calculate added/original/removed ips

Original algorithm to calculate added/removed ips had O(n^2) complexity.
Using sets achieves O(n) for average case.
After refactoring input is no longer affected,
updated tests to reflect that.
However, dataset is too small to get any significant performance
improvement.

Using sets requires additional preparation and post operations:
- converting 'original_ips' and 'new_ips' to sets from ip_addresses
- building map(dict) for storing reference from ip_address to 'ips'
  element
- converting calculated add/orignal/remove sets back to list of dicts
  using map (dict of references).

Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-ipam

Change-Id: Iecddc406f7b91cfdfb976882504113734e19b565
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/23/190623/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from sets import Set import netaddr def _needs_ip(self, context, subnet_id, device_owner): # For ports that are not router ports, retain any automatic # (non-optional, e.g. IPv6 SLAAC) addresses. if device_owner not in constants.ROUTER_INTERFACE_OWNERS: subnet = self._get_subnet(context, subnet_id) return not ipv6_utils.is_auto_address_subnet(subnet) return True add_ips = [] remove_ips = [] new = Set() new_ips_map = dict() # Builds sets from dicts where 'ip_address' exists, # If no ip_address is set, check if for ip in new_ips: if 'ip_address' in ip: # Build set with IP addresses new.add(ip['ip_address']) # Create mapping between 'ip_address' and element from new_ips new_ips_map[ip['ip_address']] = ip else: if self._needs_ip(context, ip['subnet_id'], device_owner): add_ips.append(ip) # Convert original ip addresses to sets orig = Set([ip['ip_address'] for ip in original_ips]) # Create mapping between 'ip_address' and element in original_ips orig_map = {ip['ip_address']: ip for ip in original_ips} add = new - orig original = new & orig remove = orig - new # Convert results back to list of dicts for ip_address in add: add_ips.append(new_ips_map[ip_address]) for ip_address in original: prev_ips.append(orig_map[ip_address]) for ip_address in remove: subnet_id = orig_map[ip_address]['subnet_id'] if self._needs_ip(context, subnet_id, device_owner): remove_ips.append(orig_map[ip_address]) else: prev_ips.append(orig_map[ip_address]) return {'add': add_ips, 'remove': remove_ips}
deleted_lines: import netaddr # Remove all of the intersecting elements for original_ip in original_ips[:]: for new_ip in new_ips[:]: if ('ip_address' in new_ip and original_ip['ip_address'] == new_ip['ip_address']): original_ips.remove(original_ip) new_ips.remove(new_ip) prev_ips.append(original_ip) break else: # For ports that are not router ports, retain any automatic # (non-optional, e.g. IPv6 SLAAC) addresses. if device_owner not in constants.ROUTER_INTERFACE_OWNERS: subnet = self._get_subnet(context, original_ip['subnet_id']) if (ipv6_utils.is_auto_address_subnet(subnet)): original_ips.remove(original_ip) prev_ips.append(original_ip) return {'add': new_ips, 'remove': original_ips}

subject: Unbreak the world!
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-29 18:32:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/890e09eab257091e587f5d08f7ee7e0116a4c60e', 'message': 'Remove direct calls to fixtures cleanUp()

The fixtures 1.3.0 release started enforcing that manually calling the
cleanUp() function for a fixture was a bad idea. This has been causing
several unit test failures when running with that release. This commit
addresses this by removing all the uses of this call straightup as it
turns out it was unecessary, or changing the tests to not rely on it
anymore.

Change-Id: I24f6e20cc8e310ba69fb23510795e235218abb2d
Closes-Bug: #1469825
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-06-29 18:38:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/4003bf983e6338b11e210d015c18541b8b277a01', 'message': "Remove direct calls to fixtures cleanUp()

The fixtures 1.3.0 release started enforcing that manually calling the
cleanUp() function for a fixture that was created using useFixture()
was a bad idea. It's basically saying we don't want to manage the
fixture lifecycle but at the same time want to manually run cleanUp().
This enforcement included in the new release has been causing several
unit test failures when running with that release. This commit
addresses this by removing all the uses of this call straightup as it
turns out it was unecessary, or changing the tests to not rely on it
anymore.

Change-Id: I24f6e20cc8e310ba69fb23510795e235218abb2d
Closes-Bug: #1469825

The fixtures 1.3.0 release started enforcing that manually calling the
cleanUp() function for a fixture that was created using useFixture()
was a bad idea. It's basically saying we don't want to manage the
fixture lifecycle but at the same time want to manually run cleanUp().
This enforcement included in the new release has been causing several
unit test failures when running with that release. This commit
addresses this by removing all the uses of this call straightup as it
turns out it was unecessary, or changing the tests to not rely on it
anymore.

Change-Id: I24f6e20cc8e310ba69fb23510795e235218abb2d

This commit contains 2 unrelated fixes, updates the sample config to

to fixtures cleanUp(). Normally we don't want to do this and should
have only 1 fix per patch. However, because they are both breaking the
tempest gate at the same time and preventing anything from landing if
we don't land them in a single patch neither fix will be able to land.

The fixtures 1.3.0 release started enforcing that manually calling the
cleanUp() function for a fixture that was created using useFixture()
was a bad idea. It's basically saying we don't want to manage the
fixture lifecycle but at the same time want to manually run cleanUp().
This enforcement included in the new release has been causing several
unit test failures when running with that release. This commit
addresses this by removing all the uses of this call straightup as it
turns out it was unecessary, or changing the tests to not rely on it
anymore.

Change-Id: I24f6e20cc8e310ba69fb23510795e235218abb2d
Closes-Bug: #1469825
"}]
commit_message:
Unbreak the world!

This commit contains 2 unrelated fixes, updates the sample config to
reflect changes in a recent oslo.log release and remove direct calls
to fixtures cleanUp(). Normally we don't want to do this and should
have only 1 fix per patch. However, because they are both breaking the
tempest gate at the same time and preventing anything from landing if
we don't land them in a single patch neither fix will be able to land.

The fixtures 1.3.0 release started enforcing that manually calling the
cleanUp() function for a fixture that was created using useFixture()
was a bad idea. It's basically saying we don't want to manage the
fixture lifecycle but at the same time want to manually run cleanUp().
This enforcement included in the new release has been causing several
unit test failures when running with that release. This commit
addresses this by removing all the uses of this call straightup as it
turns out it was unecessary, or changing the tests to not rely on it
anymore.

Change-Id: I24f6e20cc8e310ba69fb23510795e235218abb2d
Closes-Bug: #1469825

commit_message:
Move DB creation from database to granules

* Move Glance DB to Glance granule
* Move Keystone DB to Keystone granule
* Minor typos in Heat granule
* Move Cinder to Cinder Granule
* Move Nova to Nova granule

Partial blueprint: detach-components-from-controllers

Change-Id: Ifa2c1deef774b0fa5ea4d3b99361a5cad0c50015
Signed-off-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovatiuk@mirantis.com>

subject: Install qemu-kvm package on centos/fedora
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-26 04:50:52.000000000', 'files': ['lib/nova_plugins/functions-libvirt', 'files/rpms/nova'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/614ca26b47076321e1e06d0d79b9f7c53c5ef259', 'message': 'Install qemu-kvm package on centos/fedora

Change I79a8d8ac7ad2fbd7d2fce696821d130218e43e03 removed the install
of python-libguestfs, which was actually hiding a dependency issue on
Centos.  The "kvm" package is ultimately missing some bios files from
"seabios-bin" -- however with python-libguestfs installed this was
coming in via a dependency chain that pulled in qemu-kvm, which has
the dependency.

qemu-kvm is not strictly required as all the functionality is within
qemu-system-x86.  But while we get [1] sorted out this restores the
job functionality.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1235890

Change-Id: I3379bc497978befac48c5af0f1035b96d030b7eb
'}]
commit_message:
Install qemu-kvm package on centos/fedora

Change I79a8d8ac7ad2fbd7d2fce696821d130218e43e03 removed the install
of python-libguestfs, which was actually hiding a dependency issue on
Centos.  The "kvm" package is ultimately missing some bios files from
"seabios-bin" -- however with python-libguestfs installed this was
coming in via a dependency chain that pulled in qemu-kvm, which has
the dependency.

qemu-kvm is not strictly required as all the functionality is within
qemu-system-x86.  But while we get [1] sorted out this restores the
job functionality.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1235890

Change-Id: I3379bc497978befac48c5af0f1035b96d030b7eb

commit_message:
Add a new boot section 'trusted_boot' for PXE

Add a new boot section 'trusted_boot' for PXE to support
trusted boot. With this, Ironic can boot nodes with trusted
boot to measure BIOS, Option Rom and Kernel/Ramdisk.

Implements blueprint bare-metal-trust-using-intel-txt
Change-Id: I223569d59882c6629bfdd3a87baad6b6c853538e

commit_message:
Be more forgiving to empty context in notification

We seem to call
rpc.get_notifier('api').error(None, 'api.fault', payload) in
notifications.py, where the first parameter is context. This
eventually calls context.to_dict() in
/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/nova/rpc.py, which breaks for a
NoneType object.

Closes-Bug: 1360911

Change-Id: Idfd247ab48eb86e10f5fc73c5e24de1ca9abb0ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/26/116526/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if context: return context.to_dict() else: return {}

This reverts commit 1d61c5f736b9df7253a1939fe55f1875f988d1f4,
which reverted ee51ef72d37a02005a7733b7f2faf7236db850a1 due
to an issue with the allocation pools being mis-aligned with
the last address of a v6 subnet.

IPv6 does not have a subnet broadcast address so the last IP
address can be used as a regular address. This patch tweaks the
automatic allocation pool generation to include that last address
on v6 networks.

This was found because
NetworksTestDHCPv6.test_dhcp_stateful_fixedips_outrange makes the
assumption that the default generated pools cover the entire usable
address space.

Related-Bug: #1466322
Closes-Bug: #1468163

commit_message:
Use last address in v6 allocation pool generation

This reverts commit 1d61c5f736b9df7253a1939fe55f1875f988d1f4,
which reverted ee51ef72d37a02005a7733b7f2faf7236db850a1 due
to an issue with the allocation pools being mis-aligned with
the last address of a v6 subnet.

IPv6 does not have a subnet broadcast address so the last IP
address can be used as a regular address. This patch tweaks the
automatic allocation pool generation to include that last address
on v6 networks.

This was found because
NetworksTestDHCPv6.test_dhcp_stateful_fixedips_outrange makes the
assumption that the default generated pools cover the entire usable
address space.

Related-Bug: #1466322
Closes-Bug: #1468163
Change-Id: I5a2518c819757cd1fb43244901fe3e2f6c576b34
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/14/195014/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: last_ip = net.last if net.version == 4: # last address is broadcast in v4 last_ip -= 1

commit_message:
Retry port status update on StaleDataError

During update_port_status, a port may be concurrently updated/deleted
by another process, which will result in a StaleDataError being
thrown. In the event it was an update, we want to retry to make sure
the port status is set to the desired state so third parties like Nova
get notified.

This patch uses the oslo_db wrap_db_retry decorator after converting
the StaleDataError into a RetryRequest that the decorator can catch.

Closes-Bug: #1465407
Change-Id: I0a9230d30f435ec3d48f033136e85c40ad489ef9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/63/192063/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @oslo_db_api.wrap_db_retry(max_retries=db_api.MAX_RETRIES, retry_on_request=True) try: session.flush() # try again if port updated concurrently except sa_exc.StaleDataError as e: raise os_db_exception.RetryRequest(e) try: session.flush() # try again if port updated concurrently except sa_exc.StaleDataError as e: raise os_db_exception.RetryRequest(e)

commit_message:
acceptance: install latest openstack-selinux

Since SELinux is enforced by default, we need to make sure
openstack-selinux is installed from the latest version to have OpenStack
correctly working.

Change-Id: I4fccfe56700123143cad2548a68be748bc4630c3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/13/196813/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: package { 'openstack-selinux': ensure => 'latest' }

* Added negative tests for #service_token_set? and user_password_set?
* Added test for #version
* Fixed #unset test
* Fixed #to_env test
* In several tests, added an OS_NOT_VALID parameter to make sure the
  credentials code correctly ignores it
* Added tests to make sure the fallback in Auth.request works properly
* Added additional tests to make sure the @credentials object is set
  correctly
* Fixed some formatting/alignment issues

Change-Id: I64cb492dc244b975827d2d0d86b4b97d7129088f
"}]
commit_message:
Credentials#unset method

* Unset was broken, not resetting the variables
* Also added a rspec example

It worked but wasn't clean as if an authentication method failed some fields
could have been left un-blanked, creating bad side effects.

In addition:
* Added tests for #set with both valid and invalid values
* Added negative tests for #service_token_set? and user_password_set?
* Added test for #version
* Fixed #unset test
* Fixed #to_env test
* In several tests, added an OS_NOT_VALID parameter to make sure the
  credentials code correctly ignores it
* Added tests to make sure the fallback in Auth.request works properly
* Added additional tests to make sure the @credentials object is set
  correctly
* Fixed some formatting/alignment issues

Change-Id: I64cb492dc244b975827d2d0d86b4b97d7129088f

commit_message:
Switch from deprecated oslo_utils.timeutils.strtime

The oslo_utils.timeutils.strtime function is deprecated as of
oslo_utils 1.7.

 DeprecationWarning: Using function/method
 'oslo_utils.timeutils.strtime()' is deprecated in version '1.6'
 and will be removed in a future version: use either
 datetime.datetime.isoformat() or datetime.datetime.strftime()
 instead

Closes-Bug: 1469867
Change-Id: I97897728703547414a621b6687989cff07e01b3e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/42/196842/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def strtime(): at = timeutils.utcnow() return at.strftime(timeutils.PERFECT_TIME_FORMAT)

commit_message:
Restrict gate-horizon-jshint to older releases.

In Liberty, the horizon team is moving to using a different linter,
which is currently run under the non-voting build horizon-npm-run-lint.
This patch disables the deprecated jshint build in horizon/master,
keeping it active for icehouse, juno, and kilo.

Change-Id: Ifb59af36ae37926133769c655e54f4c2e1edf095
Partially-Implements: blueprint jscs-cleanup

commit_message:
Make package 'bridge-utils' install optional

When using puppet-nova with another big Puppet modules
this package may be defined before.

The solution is to make an installation optional.

Change-Id: I744fe89e8d9dae79a5b822ac1a1ad4cee780bfc4
Closes-Bug: #1445437

commit_message:
Do not create tun and int bridges manually

Currently integration and tunnel bridges are created by Puppet
during deployment. It looks like it's not needed anymore because
Neutron handles them itself

Change-Id: Id41071fc6128965f4d4cf6b1e03b75e91f8fbec0
Closes-bug: #1436422

commit_message:
Install only required libvirt packages

In RH platform package libvirt is metapackage pulling unnecessary packages.
This patch implements installation of required packages only according to
virt_type parameter.

Change-Id: I68f7ade87dc5371d9bbfc79eafb528293f613375

commit_message:
Revert "Removed test_lib module"

This reverts commit 9a6536de6e1a7fe9b2552adc142e254426b82b6f.

We pulled all of the plugins out of the tree, many of which still inherit
from neutron test classes. This change then stated that we no longer
support testing other plugins. I think this is a bit premature and should
have been discussed under the subject 
"Neutron plugins can't use neutron plugin unit tests" or something
similar.

Change-Id: I68318589f010b731574ea3bfa8df98492bab31fc

commit_message:
Move lock_path into oslo_concurrency section

[DEFAULT]/lock_path is deprecated, it has moved into [oslo_concurrency].

See more info:
  https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/master/etc/manila/README.manila.conf

Change-Id: I1984d3b9b39ad5c66113fd19c3e5486e44f88780
Closes-Bug: 1447889
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-manila refs/changes/71/177071/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'oslo_concurrency/lock_path': value => $lock_path;

commit_message:
Switch to oslo.service

oslo.service has graduated, so cinder should consume it.

Change-Id: I80487f559302b0e88953835ffb4a3bfe2a347501
Closes-Bug: #1466851
Depends-On: I305cf53bad6213c151395e93d656b53a8a28e1db

deleted_lines: # Copyright 2012-2014 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Helper module for systemd service readiness notification. """ import logging import os import socket import sys LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def _abstractify(socket_name): if socket_name.startswith('@'): # abstract namespace socket socket_name = '\0%s' % socket_name[1:] return socket_name def _sd_notify(unset_env, msg): notify_socket = os.getenv('NOTIFY_SOCKET') if notify_socket: sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_UNIX, socket.SOCK_DGRAM) try: sock.connect(_abstractify(notify_socket)) sock.sendall(msg) if unset_env: del os.environ['NOTIFY_SOCKET'] except EnvironmentError: LOG.debug("Systemd notification failed", exc_info=True) finally: sock.close() def notify(): """Send notification to Systemd that service is ready. For details see http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/sd_notify.html """ _sd_notify(False, 'READY=1') def notify_once(): """Send notification once to Systemd that service is ready. Systemd sets NOTIFY_SOCKET environment variable with the name of the socket listening for notifications from services. This method removes the NOTIFY_SOCKET environment variable to ensure notification is sent only once. """ _sd_notify(True, 'READY=1') def onready(notify_socket, timeout): """Wait for systemd style notification on the socket. :param notify_socket: local socket address :type notify_socket: string :param timeout: socket timeout :type timeout: float :returns: 0 service ready 1 service not ready 2 timeout occurred """ sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_UNIX, socket.SOCK_DGRAM) sock.settimeout(timeout) sock.bind(_abstractify(notify_socket)) try: msg = sock.recv(512) except socket.timeout: return 2 finally: sock.close() if 'READY=1' in msg: return 0 else: return 1 if __name__ == '__main__': # simple CLI for testing if len(sys.argv) == 1: notify() elif len(sys.argv) >= 2: timeout = float(sys.argv[1]) notify_socket = os.getenv('NOTIFY_SOCKET') if notify_socket: retval = onready(notify_socket, timeout) sys.exit(retval)

commit_message:
Ensure /etc/nova exists before creating secret.xml

Without declaring a dependency, secret.xml can be
created before the folder is created through
the installation of the nova packages.

Closes-bug: #1458628
Change-Id: I0b9aec13866e4e334bcaf967192b2bc310ae20fb
(cherry picked from commit 7d1171986eb7a6115c35ebb3d8bba155ca8ecd04)

commit_message:
acceptance: install latest openstack-selinux

Since SELinux is enforced by default, we need to make sure
openstack-selinux is installed from the latest version to have OpenStack
correctly working.

Change-Id: I0b904b0f325a10ee952f07c5b3556765b53bf267

commit_message:
Fix Python 3 issues in ceph and rbd drivers

* Add cinder.utils.convert_str() function: helper to convert a string to
  a native string: convert to bytes on Python 2, convert to Unicode on
  Python 3. Function needed by ceph and rbd drivers.
* Replace encodeutils.safe_encode() with utils.convert_str()
* test_backup_ceph: get the size of the volume file using os.fstat() to
  fix a test. Before the volume size was a mock, but comparison between
  integers and mocks raise a TypeError on Python 3.
* Fix RBDDriver._update_volume_stats(): replace a/b with a//b to get an integer
  on Python 2 and Python 3 (a/b always returns a float on Python 3)
* Replace map() with a list-comprehension in RBDDriver because a list is
  expected. On Python 3, map() returns an iterator.
* tox.ini: add to following tests to Python 3.4

  - cinder.tests.unit.test_backup_ceph
  - cinder.tests.unit.test_rbd

Blueprint cinder-python3
Change-Id: I7acb0d9eed0d351798133e0c6ef55408fed925dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/88/194588/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_utils import encodeutils def convert_str(text): """Convert to native string. Convert bytes and Unicode strings to native strings: * convert to bytes on Python 2: encode Unicode using encodeutils.safe_encode() * convert to Unicode on Python 3: decode bytes from UTF-8 """ if six.PY2: return encodeutils.safe_encode(text) else: if isinstance(text, bytes): return text.decode('utf-8') else: return text

commit_message:
Convert keystone from eventlet to httpd

eventlet in master (Delorean) has had a regression making Keystone
not work well with it.  Instead, we have decided to switch to the
recommended deployment model using httpd.

Change-Id: Ie5407ae4fab9882b301925ddfa1b065923bbd52f
Closes-Bug: #1469851
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/54/196854/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: /usr/sbin/httpd -DFOREGROUND &

commit_message:
beaker: test to list keystone resources

* Modify default endpoints to use 127.0.0.1 instead of FQDN that might
  not be resolvable all the time.
* Drop HTTPS from default endpoints (SSL is not configured).
* Add serverspec tests to validate Keystone resources.

Change-Id: I2e8e5bc9a4969e75eca4912a0c459e8576164f24

added_lines: public_url => "http://${::fqdn}:5000/", admin_url => "http://${::fqdn}:35357/", class { '::openstack_extras::auth_file': password => 'a_big_secret', auth_url => 'http://${::fqdn}:5000/v2.0/' } shell('source <(sudo cat /root/openrc)') describe 'test keystone user/service/endpoint/role' do it 'should find admin user' do expect(shell("keystone user-list | grep -q admin ").exit_code).to be_zero end end

subject: Fullstack resources should always be cleaned up
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-11 17:28:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/767004fff902e1b680954dcf33f5072c2224a4e6', 'message': "Fullstack resources should always be cleaned up

Normally, a Fixture which raises an exception on setUp() doesn't call
cleanUp(). In case the framework raises an exception during the setUp of
such a fixture (specifically, the EnvironmentFixture, responsible for
creating all the processes and resources), it won't cleaned.

A specific function that can raise an exception like this is if one of
the processes failed to start. In this case, an eventlet.timeout.Timeout
exception is raised and the cleanUp is never called. This patch adds a
try-except block around the timeout-invoking function and makes sure to
cleanUp() the resources before re-raising the error.

Change-Id: If96acc21545abb038ba54c2b6072252095370af5
Closes-bug: #1453888
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-05-14 17:56:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/8fc5de4eda37493cf8c3f2a17b6f79ba6ff39e3e', 'message': "Fullstack resources should always be cleaned up

commit_message:
Fullstack resources should always be cleaned up

Normally, a Fixture which raises an exception on setUp() doesn't call
cleanUp(). In case the framework raises an exception during the setUp of
such a fixture (specifically, the EnvironmentFixture, responsible for
creating all the processes and resources), it won't cleaned.

A specific function that can raise an exception like this is if one of
the processes failed to start. In this case, an eventlet.timeout.Timeout
exception is raised and the cleanUp is never called. This patch adds a
try-except block around the timeout-invoking function and makes sure to
cleanUp() the resources before re-raising the error.

Change-Id: If96acc21545abb038ba54c2b6072252095370af5
Closes-bug: #1453888
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/91/181991/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import eventlet try: utils.wait_until_true( functools.partial(self._processes_are_ready, agents_count)) except eventlet.timeout.Timeout: self.cleanUp() raise

subject: Add test case for deleting endpoint with space in url
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-29 21:50:20.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/tests/unit/test_v3_catalog.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/83b56f4b6a6ad80e090e92514d92a4ac8b562e0f', 'message': 'Add test case for deleting endpoint with space in url

In the bug report, creating an endpoint with "tenant_i d" in any of
its URLs (internal, public, or admin/auth) allegedly prevented the
endpoint from being deleted.

This addition to another test case adds a space to all 3 URLs of an
endpoint.  It then gets the amount of current endpoints, deletes the
endpoint, and makes sure there is one less endpoint after attempting
to delete.

Change-Id: Icb63b1090468ad7c02a4a6ea26f85ab8c8371f04
Closes-Bug: #1098564
'}]
commit_message:
Add test case for deleting endpoint with space in url

In the bug report, creating an endpoint with "tenant_i d" in any of
its URLs (internal, public, or admin/auth) allegedly prevented the
endpoint from being deleted.

This addition to another test case adds a space to all 3 URLs of an
endpoint.  It then gets the amount of current endpoints, deletes the
endpoint, and makes sure there is one less endpoint after attempting
to delete.

Change-Id: Icb63b1090468ad7c02a4a6ea26f85ab8c8371f04
Closes-Bug: #1098564
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/80/196880/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: v2_id = endpoint_v2['id'] v3_id = endpoint_v3['id'] self.assertNotEqual(v2_id, v3_id) # test for bug 1098564 -- endpoint didn't delete with a space in a url # add a space to all urls url_with_space = "http://127.0.0.1:8774 /v1.1/\$(tenant_i d)s" ref['publicurl'] = url_with_space ref['internalurl'] = url_with_space ref['adminurl'] = url_with_space endpoint_v3['url'] = url_with_space # get the size of the endpoint list before deleting r = self.get('/endpoints') endpoints = self.assertValidEndpointListResponse(r) length_before = len(endpoints) # delete the endpoint self.delete( '/endpoints/%(endpoint_id)s' % { 'endpoint_id': v3_id}) r = self.get('/endpoints') # make sure it was deleted properly (list should shrink by 1) endpoints = self.assertValidEndpointListResponse(r) length_after = len(endpoints) self.assertEqual(length_after, length_before - 1)

commit_message:
acceptance: install latest openstack-selinux

Since SELinux is enforced by default, we need to make sure
openstack-selinux is installed from the latest version to have OpenStack
correctly working.

Change-Id: Ib07d2a724c0cf0ac78cc656fcdcef849f05ea8b7

commit_message:
Cleanup Glance references

Update references from Glance to Searchlight at gitignore and HACKING.
Additionally remove migrate_image_owners script from tools directory as
it belongs to Glance (it's importing modules from Glance, so it's making
strict dependency to it).

Change-Id: I2ab1ae28545f8d5f5eecb3e2bcb0d8a49c5def26

added_lines: The cinder module is a part of [OpenStack](https://github.com/openstack), an effort by the Openstack infrastructure team to provide continuous integration testing and code review for Openstack and Openstack community projects as part of the core software. The module its self is used to flexibly configure and manage the block storage service for Openstack.This module is tested in combination with other modules needed to build and leverage an entire Openstack software stack. These modules can be found, all pulled together in the [openstack module](https://github.com/stackforge/puppet-openstack).To utilize the cinder module's functionality you will need to declare multiple resources. subject: Fix tenant-id in Arista ML2 driver to support HA router
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-27 01:39:31.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/arista/mechanism_arista.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ab3046d3f8375db404aa316477b4be15ad7f2bd2', 'message': 'Fix tenant-id in Arista ML2 driver to support HA router

When HA router is created, the framework creates a network and does
not specify the tenant-id. This casuse Arista ML2 driver to fail.
This patch sets the tenant-id when it is not passed explicitly by
by the network_create() call from the HA router framework.

Even though original issue was discovered for network_create()
it turns out the same issue applies for port_create() as well
so all the methods are fixed in this patch

Change-Id: Id03e26dac003fa589477ed78a4ed3c44cc2f708d
Closes-Bug: 1468828
(cherry picked from commit 0a2238e34e72c17ca8a75e36b1f56e41a3ece74e)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix tenant-id in Arista ML2 driver to support HA router

When HA router is created, the framework creates a network and does
not specify the tenant-id. This casuse Arista ML2 driver to fail.
This patch sets the tenant-id when it is not passed explicitly by
by the network_create() call from the HA router framework.

Even though original issue was discovered for network_create()
it turns out the same issue applies for port_create() as well
so all the methods are fixed in this patch

Change-Id: Id03e26dac003fa589477ed78a4ed3c44cc2f708d
Closes-Bug: 1468828
(cherry picked from commit 0a2238e34e72c17ca8a75e36b1f56e41a3ece74e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/26/196326/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not tenant_id: tenant_id = context._plugin_context.tenant_id if not tenant_id: tenant_id = context._plugin_context.tenant_id if not tenant_id: tenant_id = context._plugin_context.tenant_id if not tenant_id: tenant_id = context._plugin_context.tenant_id if not tenant_id: tenant_id = context._plugin_context.tenant_id if not tenant_id: tenant_id = context._plugin_context.tenant_id if not tenant_id: tenant_id = context._plugin_context.tenant_id if not tenant_id: tenant_id = context._plugin_context.tenant_id if not tenant_id: tenant_id = context._plugin_context.tenant_id

commit_message:
Downgrade hardcoded /tmp confidence

This commit downgrades confidence for the hardcoded /tmp check to
reflect that all we're doing is matching a hardcoded string.

Change-Id: I2aa124cd589808d42372649774ba46eedbd7d88d

deleted_lines: confidence=bandit.MEDIUM, text="Probable insecure usage of temp file/directory."

commit_message:
Make test_ensure_mysql_is_running more robust

Currently ensure_mysql_is_running test function uses an
Ubuntu-specific check for the presence of the mysqld process.
Make this more general to support other distros without
losing existing compatibility.

Change-Id: Ib989496b5dab7cce8d88532a2d032a128126c01a
Closes-Bug: 1469543

subject: Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-26 22:20:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/solum/commit/3216e4be335aa01527767fe90bcc9521d0630a94', 'message': "Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new
versions of the libraries without namespace packages will be released as
a major version update.

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

commit_message:
Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new
versions of the libraries without namespace packages will be released as
a major version update.

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

Change-Id: I5e2f3d91bf02d6a00ef0e90961b479e0e9323c8c

commit_message:
disable coverage test temporarily

Fixtures upgrade breaks us now, and the workaround patch is blocked by
coverage test. Because coverage compares unit tests on both master and
HEAD, the coverage on master (without workaround patch)can't finish for
the reason of fixtures. So we have to disable coverage test for a while,
and then merge workaround patch. At last, we could enable it back or
revirt this patch.

Change-Id: I53d50eb7bd235e058f7e8649afbac5792fd05d8d

commit_message:
Allow logging hookpoint intialization

The hook points are applied prior to any logging configuration. This
makes it difficult for a hook author to ensure that the correct
configuration and package entry points have been added. This patch takes
the log messages and buffers them for replay after the logging has been
configure. The replay function is then called in each of the commands
after the configuration has been read.

Closes-Bug: #1465731
Change-Id: Ia5cc2dba53056c55017b3a104a1f4e22e6594ae0

commit_message:
Add FIO disk benchmark for VMs

This patch adds `fio' [1] disk benchmark installation and execution
scripts for VM benchmarks.

[1] https://github.com/axboe/fio

Change-Id: I0c37559152a9f1f51e593a2b639a51d6b740acb4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/88/152388/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/sh set -e readonly DISTFILE="https://github.com/axboe/fio/archive/fio-2.2.5.tar.gz" err() { echo "[$(date +'%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S %z')]: ${@}" >&2 exit 1 } assert_superuser() { test $(/usr/bin/id -u) -eq 0 ||\ err "Only the superuser (uid 0) can use this script." } test_benchmark() { /usr/bin/fio -h } build_benchmark() { wget "${DISTFILE}" local archive="${DISTFILE##*/}" tar -x -z -f "${archive}" cd fio-fio-* ./configure make # make install cp fio /usr/bin cd .. rm -fr fio-* } install_benchmark_dependencies() { local os="${1}" case "${os}" in "rhel"|"centos"|"fedora") yum -y install wget gcc make gzip libaio libaio-devel ;; "ubuntu"|"debian") apt-get update apt-get -y dist-upgrade apt-get -y install make gcc libaio libaio-dev ;; esac } uninstall_benchmark_build_dependencies() { local os="${1}" case "${os}" in "rhel"|"centos"|"fedora") yum -y remove wget gcc make libaio-devel ;; "ubuntu"|"debian") apt-get update apt-get -y dist-upgrade apt-get -y remove make gcc libaio-dev ;; esac } identify_operating_system() { local os="unknown" if [ -f "/etc/centos-release" ]; then os="centos" elif [ -f "/etc/fedora-release" ]; then os="fedora" elif [ -f "/etc/redhat-release" ]; then os="rhel" elif [ -f "/etc/os-release" ]; then local name=$(grep '^NAME=' "/etc/os-release" | cut -d '"' -f 2) if [ "${name}" = "Debian GNU/Linux" ]; then os="debian" elif [ "${name}" = "Ubuntu" ]; then os="ubuntu" fi fi echo ${os} } main() { assert_superuser local os=$(identify_operating_system) test "${os}" = "unknown" &&\ err "Unable to identify the operating system." install_benchmark_dependencies "${os}" build_benchmark test_benchmark uninstall_benchmark_build_dependencies "${os}" } main

commit_message:
Unify the use of "<filename>...</filename> file"

We normally use "<filename>FILE</filename> file" and not
"<filename>cinder.conf</filename> configuration file".

Change-Id: Ic8f809dc06ef45b9c61d489a1a0395e13e34d0f4

commit_message:
Use the requirements parser.

This switches the requirements parser from a local one to using the
reference one in openstack/requirements. To do that I install the
openstack/requirements we're testing against in a virtualenv and
import it. We could if wanted install that separately and run it
against a just in time checkout, but this should be reliable for now
(though the need to encode a python path in a venv is a little ugly).

Change-Id: I1f77a2e0eaa7046928642cf0b9e2c490a851a303

commit_message:
JSCS Cleanup - style cleanup for Launch Instance Source Step

Following John Papa's style guide
https://github.com/johnpapa/angular-styleguide,
this patch refactors the Angular code for the 'source' step
in Launch Instance wizard.

Change-Id: I195aa852a43462b8967d0f1faaea089906cc0a05
Partially-Implements: blueprint jscs-cleanup

commit_message:
neutron: allow to enable qos service plugin in gate

This is needed so that we can introduce gate jobs for feature/qos
neutron branch that actually uses the new service plugin.

Change-Id: I6686bf55c4dd2e1de85fd019b2c3134b57dec046

commit_message:
Add six and oslo.utils to requirements

Running "pip-missing-reqs" tox target showed these references
in our code. Since we refer to them directly, we should add
them to our requirements.

Change-Id: I3fdd8fa2ac7d5c1a6316874b179ef7a638540451

commit_message:
Address multiline node lineno inaccuracies

This change addresses the bug where inaccurate line numbers / ranges
are displayed when an issue is detected in a multiline statement.

There's been a Python issue open since 2012 about this:
http://bugs.python.org/issue16806

Two main parts to the commit:
 - Modify StatementBuffer so get_next() will allow lookahead without
   popping the item off the buffer.
 - Add cleverness to visit() so if it does come across a multiline
   statement, it updates the context linerange based on information
   pulled out of the StatementBuffer.

Also of note, the commit includes several new tests for fix
verification. Seemingly non-deterministic test results were driving
me batty until the need to move the BanditResultStore 'resstore =
OrderedDict()' call from class-level to object instantion became
obvious.

Change-Id: I7dd4c563f6b2f8a103224854f0709068af093a73
Closes-Bug: 1467636
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bandit refs/changes/61/195761/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_next(self, pop=True): :param pop: shift next statement off array (default) or just lookahead if pop: # shift the next statement off the array statement['node'] = self._buffer.pop(0) else: # get the next statement without shift statement['node'] = self._buffer[-1] # deal with multiline strings lineno behavior (Python issue #16806) current_lineno = self.context['lineno'] next_statement = self.stmt_buffer.get_next(pop=False) if next_statement is not None: next_lineno = min(next_statement['linerange']) else: next_lineno = self.stmt_buffer.file_len if next_lineno - current_lineno > 1: self.context['statement']['linerange'] = range(current_lineno, next_lineno)
deleted_lines: def get_next(self): # Update the context, and shift the next statement off the array statement['node'] = self._buffer.pop(0)

subject: Optimize Python install in deploy-targetcli
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-17 17:26:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/68212d7d4047bc339ba4e7dd81508a7e58bb6f9a', 'message': "Use dracut inst_multiple to install Python

Installing all of the files individually takes forever.  I'm hoping
that this will be noticeably faster.

Change-Id: Ibc2b778c28fc9fb7177380dffe8dbce5722d0733
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-06-22 18:27:21.000000000', 'files': ['elements/deploy-targetcli/extra-data.d/module/module-setup.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/3f3cded06b6d910e3686e088967a9ff633484ef8', 'message': "Optimize Python install in deploy-targetcli

Installing Python to a ramdisk takes quite a long time because of
the way dracut checks for dependencies of every single file
installed.  We could avoid that, but then we might miss a required
library file.

This change alters the installation method to speed up
the process.  First, it creates a list of files that are needed and
then installs them all at once using inst_multiple instead of calling
inst on each file separately.  This doesn't make a huge difference,
but in my testing it is marginally faster.

Second, and more significantly, we don't need the *.pyo and *.pyc
files as those are simply an optimization to speed up module
loading.  Because the deploy ramdisk is a short-lived operation,
we probably lose more time transferring those extra files to the
target system than we save in improved load times.

In my testing, these two changes netted about a 20% improvement
in build times, and about 13% decrease in image size.

Change-Id: Ibc2b778c28fc9fb7177380dffe8dbce5722d0733
"}]
commit_message:
Optimize Python install in deploy-targetcli

Installing Python to a ramdisk takes quite a long time because of
the way dracut checks for dependencies of every single file
installed.  We could avoid that, but then we might miss a required
library file.

This change alters the installation method to speed up
the process.  First, it creates a list of files that are needed and
then installs them all at once using inst_multiple instead of calling
inst on each file separately.  This doesn't make a huge difference,
but in my testing it is marginally faster.

Second, and more significantly, we don't need the *.pyo and *.pyc
files as those are simply an optimization to speed up module
loading.  Because the deploy ramdisk is a short-lived operation,
we probably lose more time transferring those extra files to the
target system than we save in improved load times.

In my testing, these two changes netted about a 20% improvement
in build times, and about 13% decrease in image size.

Change-Id: Ibc2b778c28fc9fb7177380dffe8dbce5722d0733

commit_message:
Removed test_lib module

It's not really needed. It was once used to allow some out-of-tox plugin
specific testing scripts to inject configuration files into
BaseTestCase.

Now, our testing story does not have any notion of out-of-gate plugin
specific testing, so let's just clean it up.

Change-Id: If287a38e80016b1dba049a2b745bad7af40583a8

commit_message:
AngularJS in Horizon Documentation

This patch is a first pass at reducing the levels of "tribal knowledge"
and making the AngularJS codebase more accessible. It details code
style, file structures, testing and translation.

Change-Id: I22e6e5627216739fc92a5c9a5b417c6c6b16476d
Closes-Bug: 1373310
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/43/182243/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ===================== AngularJS Topic Guide ===================== .. Note:: This guide is a work in progress. It has been uploaded to encourage faster reviewing and code development in Angular, and to help the community standardise on a set of guidelines. Code Style ========== We currently use the `Angular Style Guide`_ by John Papa as reference material. JSHint is a tool we use to automate some checking of JS code quality, and is part of the automated tests run by Jenkins. You are encouraged to configure any code editing tools to use JSHint, using the `official documentation`_ or the `OpenStack-specific documentation`_. Once installed, you can run JSHint from the horizon root directory with ``./run_test.sh --jshint``. For an example setup, see this :doc:`.jshintrc</ref/jshint>`. An explanation of the options, and details of others you may want to use, can `be found here`_. .. _Angular Style Guide: https://github.com/johnpapa/angular-styleguide .. _official documentation: http://jshint.com/install/ .. _OpenStack-specific documentation: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Horizon/Javascript/EditorConfig .. _be found here: http://jshint.com/docs/options/ File Structure ============== This folder should include the styling (``.scss``), as well as templates (``.html``) and tests (``.spec.js``). You may also include examples; append ``.example`` to the filename. The transfer-table directive is a good example of the file structure: :: horizon/horizon/static/angular/transfer-table/ ├── allocated.html.example ├── available.html.example ├── transfer-table.html ├── transfer-table.js ├── transfer-table.scss └── transfer-table.spec.js For larger components, such as workflows with multiple steps, consider breaking the code down into multiple folders. The Angular ``Launch Instance`` workflow, for example, has one folder per step. `Reusable Components`_ are in ``/horizon/static/angular/``. Panel-specific code is in ``/horizon/static/dashboard/``. Testing ======= We utilise Jasmine_ to test JavaScript code. Jasmine uses specs (``.spec.js``) which are kept with the JavaScript files that they are testing. See `File Structure`_ for more detail on this. Tests can be run in two ways: 1. Go to <dev_server>/jasmine. The development server can be run with ``./run_tests.sh --runserver`` from the horizon root directory. 2. ``./run_tests.sh --only-selenium`` from the horizon root directory. For more detailed information, see :doc:`jasmine`. .. _Jasmine: http://jasmine.github.io/2.1/introduction.html Translation (Internationalisation and Localisation) =================================================== Use either ``gettext`` or ``ngettext``: :: gettext('text to be translated'); ngettext('text to be translated'); Translations are handled in Transifex, as with Django. They are merged daily with the horizon upstream codebase. See :doc: Reusable Components =================== When writing logic, consider whether it is panel-specific or could be reused elswhere. Reusable components should be broken out and stored in ``/horizon/static/angular/COMPONENT_NAME``. Creating your own panel ======================= This sections serves as a basic introduction to writing your own panel for horizon, using AngularJS. Code specific to a panel should be stored in ``/horizon/static/dashboard/COMPONENT_NAME``. If you are adding a panel to the upstream OpenStack Dashboard project, add the relevant ``.js`` and ``.spec.js`` files to one of the dashboards in ``horizon/openstack_dashboard/enabled/``. For code that is not going upstream, you have two options: 1. Add a new panel/ panel_group/ dashboard (See :doc:`tutorial`) and then include the relevant files as follows: :: ADD_JS_FILES = [ ... 'path_to/my_angular_code.js', ... ] ADD_JS_SPEC_FILES = [ ... 'path_to/my_angular_code.spec.js', ... ] An example of this can be found at ``horizon/openstack_dashboard/enabled/_10_project.py``. 2. Add your ``.js`` and ``.spec.js`` files to either ``horizon/openstack_dashboard/settings.py`` or ``horizon/openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py``. The relevant arrays are ``'js_files'`` and ``'js_spec_files'``, inside the ``HORIZON_CONFIG`` dict. Generally ``settings.py`` will be used for higher level versions, such as a customised release of OpenStack, whereas ``local_settings.py`` will be used for specific deployments of horizon.

commit_message:
Add edit-constraints command.

This allows shell editing of a constraints file, which we need to do
in devstack when installing a constrained library from git.

Change-Id: Ibdbfc786b5d2f56d2e41d329c8766bef7b2e6854

commit_message:
"Get me a network" spec

Neutron has a lot of concepts that some users don't want or need to
understand, but must be configured if 'nova boot' is to succeed in
a Neutron-based deployment. For this reason, the bar has been set
a little too high for those users migrating from a Nova-network based
deployment (where network are pre-defined by the admin), to a Neutron-
based one, where users get to define their own networks.

Documenting how administrators can ease this transition is required,
this spec is a step at addressing this, and outlines the options and
some possible future enhancements for Neutron.

Change-Id: Id743b8989cab3fb13cf6f079acc4dedf80039e19
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/57/184857/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Get me a Network ========================================== Problem Description =================== One of the major differences that an OpenStack user who uses a Nova-Network based cloud, compared to a Neutron based cloud, is in the invocation syntax of "nova boot" For a Nova-Network based cloud, the invocation syntax is as follows .. code:: nova boot --flavor <flavor> --image <image> Networks are automatically allocated and deallocated to tenants in a Nova-Network environment, and the user is not required to specify any networking information. In a Neutron based cloud, this is not the case. A user that attempts to use "nova boot" without specifying the networking information will return an error, and an instance will not be provisioned. There are parts of OpenStack that already experience this issue, and are `forced to create client-side workarounds <https://github.com/openstack-dev/grenade/blob/master/projects/60_nova/resources.sh#L75>`_ Proposed Change =============== Ideally, a new API method will be created in Neutron that will create all the required Networking objects that are required for a booted instance to reach the internet. This means the following actions are currently required: #. Create a Neutron Network #. Create a Neutron Subnet for addressing #. Create a Neutron Router #. Wire up the router (port attach, gateway set) Data Model Impact ----------------- REST API Impact --------------- Security Impact --------------- Notifications Impact -------------------- Other End User Impact --------------------- Performance Impact ------------------ IPv6 Impact ----------- Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Developer Impact ---------------- Community Impact ---------------- Alternatives ------------ Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- Functional Tests ---------------- API Tests --------- Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Developer Documentation ----------------------- References ==========

commit_message:
Update README.rst and remove ancient reference

There's no need to give a shout out to a project that is going on
6 years old and has been deprecated.

Also provide more valuable links, such as where we track bugs, our
source code, and docs.

Change-Id: I9ea5ca83366f9dc0b2732c5db017257a1250fc05

This code is a fork of Rackspace's python-novaclient which is in turn a fork of `Jacobian's python-cloudservers <http://github.com/jacobian/python-cloudservers>`_. ``python-keystoneclient`` is licensed under the Apache License like the rest of OpenStack.

commit_message:
repo/redhat: manage EPEL with metalink instead of baseurl

Yum can process the mirror list in metalink format, which provides additional
security checking capability.
Yum compares the SHA1 checksums of each repository's repomd.xml file against
that of the master mirrors.
This ensures that significantly out-of-date mirrors are not used and
should reduce our CI timeouts issues.

Change-Id: I5beb0de2bca28b12001aaae01b5503d69bfb7727

commit_message:
Remove bgpvpn module when useless

Several parts of the code belong to a bgpvpn module that is alone
in its parent's module.
This is not needed, and complexify the code.

Change-Id: Idf1f90a050c059e84bd3f054ca8a1a42d581c052

added_lines: @base.skip_without_vpc() def test_tag_customer_gateway(self): data = self.client.create_customer_gateway( Type='ipsec.1', PublicIp='198.51.100.77', BgpAsn=65000) cgw_id = data['CustomerGateway']['CustomerGatewayId'] self.addResourceCleanUp(self.client.delete_customer_gateway, CustomerGatewayId=cgw_id) def describe_func(*args, **kwargs): data = self.client.describe_customer_gateways(*args, **kwargs) self.assertEqual(1, len(data['CustomerGateways'])) self.assertEqual(cgw_id, data['CustomerGateways'][0]['CustomerGatewayId']) self._test_tag_resource(cgw_id, 'customer-gateway', describe_func) @base.skip_without_vpc() def test_tag_vpn_gateway(self): data = self.client.create_vpn_gateway(Type='ipsec.1') vgw_id = data['VpnGateway']['VpnGatewayId'] self.addResourceCleanUp(self.client.delete_vpn_gateway, VpnGatewayId=vgw_id) def describe_func(*args, **kwargs): data = self.client.describe_vpn_gateways(*args, **kwargs) self.assertEqual(1, len(data['VpnGateways'])) self.assertEqual(vgw_id, data['VpnGateways'][0]['VpnGatewayId']) self._test_tag_resource(vgw_id, 'vpn-gateway', describe_func) @base.skip_without_vpc() def test_tag_vpn_connection(self): data = self.client.create_customer_gateway( Type='ipsec.1', PublicIp='198.51.100.77', BgpAsn=65000) cgw_id = data['CustomerGateway']['CustomerGatewayId'] self.addResourceCleanUp(self.client.delete_customer_gateway, CustomerGatewayId=cgw_id) data = self.client.create_vpn_gateway(Type='ipsec.1') vgw_id = data['VpnGateway']['VpnGatewayId'] self.addResourceCleanUp(self.client.delete_vpn_gateway, VpnGatewayId=vgw_id) data = self.client.create_vpn_connection( CustomerGatewayId=cgw_id, VpnGatewayId=vgw_id, Options={'StaticRoutesOnly': True}, Type='ipsec.1') vpn_id = data['VpnConnection']['VpnConnectionId'] vpn_clean = self.addResourceCleanUp(self.client.delete_vpn_connection, VpnConnectionId=vpn_id) def describe_func(*args, **kwargs): data = self.client.describe_vpn_connections(*args, **kwargs) self.assertEqual(1, len(data['VpnConnections'])) self.assertEqual(vpn_id, data['VpnConnections'][0]['VpnConnectionId']) self._test_tag_resource(vpn_id, 'vpn-connection', describe_func) self.client.delete_vpn_connection(VpnConnectionId=vpn_id) vpn_waiter = self.get_vpn_connection_waiter() self.cancelResourceCleanUp(vpn_clean) vpn_waiter.wait_delete(vpn_id)

commit_message:
Fix 404 links in fuel-dev docs

Fix 404 links in fuel-dev docs discovered through a linkcheck
jenkins job that is now automatically run daily. You can check it here:
https://ci.fuel-infra.org/view/All/job/fuel-web-linkcheck/
The missing.txt file.

Change-Id: Ieada5ff9a09305f6f498c79528a5ae3577f51781

commit_message:
Install oslo.service via pip

python-oslo-service is not yet packaged for Delorean, causing
multiple services that have switched to this library to break.
To resolve that problem, we have a short term fix of installing
the oslo.service via pip in the base image.

Change-Id: Iff3410ec90b25b239ee49cc725ef224fa80e7aee
Closes-Bug: #1469821
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/77/196777/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: # TODO(inc0): when oslo_service lands in delorean, change pip to yum # necessary until https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1229477 is fixed RUN yum -y install python-oslo-policy && yum clean all && pip install oslo.service

added_lines: ========== volume qos ========== volume v1, v2 volume qos associate -------------------- Associate a QoS specification to a volume type .. program:: volume qos associate .. code:: bash os volume qos associate <qos-specs> <volume-type> .. describe:: <qos-specs> QoS specification to modify (name or ID) .. describe:: <volume-type> Volume type to associate the QoS (name or ID) volume qos create ----------------- Create new QoS Specification .. program:: volume qos create .. code:: bash os volume qos create [--consumer <consumer>] [--property <key=value> [...] ] <name> .. option:: --consumer <consumer> Consumer of the QoS. Valid consumers: 'front-end', 'back-end', 'both' (defaults to 'both') .. option:: --property <key=value> Set a property on this QoS specification (repeat option to set multiple properties) .. describe:: <name> New QoS specification name volume qos delete ----------------- Delete QoS specification .. program:: volume qos delete .. code:: bash os volume qos delete <qos_specs> .. describe:: <volume qos> QoS specification to delete (name or ID) volume qos disassociate ----------------------- Disassociate a QoS specification from a volume type .. program:: volume qos disassoiate .. code:: bash os volume qos disassociate --volume-type <volume-type> | --all <qos-specs> .. option:: --volume-type <volume-type> Volume type to disassociate the QoS from (name or ID) .. option:: --all Disassociate the QoS from every volume type .. describe:: <qos-specs> QoS specification to modify (name or ID) volume qos list --------------- List QoS specifications .. program:: volume qos list .. code:: bash os volume qos list volume qos set -------------- Set QoS specification properties .. program:: volume qos set .. code:: bash os volume qos set [--property <key=value> [...] ] <qos-specs> .. option:: --property <key=value> Property to add or modify for this QoS specification (repeat option to set multiple properties) .. describe:: <volume qos> QoS specification to modify (name or ID) volume qos show --------------- Display QoS specification details .. program:: volume qos show .. code:: bash os volume qos show <qos-specs> .. describe:: <volume qos> QoS specification to display (name or ID) volume qos unset ---------------- Unset QoS specification properties .. program:: volume qos unset .. code:: bash os volume qos unset [--property <key>] <qos-specs> .. option:: --property <key> Property to remove from QoS specification (repeat option to remove multiple properties) .. describe:: <volume qos> QoS specification to modify (name or ID)

commit_message:
Revert "Disable backup progress notifications for unit tests"

This reverts commit e5f6ed69e0031900f97da185b5363ebd3dd60c0c.

This was an attempted workaround for the notifier issue.
It's not needed now that the fake notifier has been fixed,
so restore the default behavior.

Also remove conf imports which were added in commit d9b9ac
to fix commit e5f6ed.

Related-Bug: #1412513

Change-Id: Id0d547e3c2faa8c1a0555e28cdb2e9d83956c1ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/79/193579/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add a script to populate a Zanata project

Currently, the Zanata server has all of the OpenStack projects
configured, but there are no source documents and no translations
for them. Concoct a script that will pull all translations from
Transifex and then push them up with current source documents to
our Zanata server.

Change-Id: Ic5c28f4ed238314d82919a7e6eb8fe64b804a220
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/21/195421/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash -xe # Copyright (c) 2015 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. PROJECT=$1 source /usr/local/jenkins/slave_scripts/common_translation_update.sh setup_translation case "$PROJECT" in django-openstack_auth) setup_django_openstack_auth ;; horizon) setup_horizon ;; *) setup_project "$PROJECT" ;; esac # Download all files from transifex tx pull -a -f # And upload them to Zanata zanata-cli -B -e push --push-type both # Undo everything we did locally git reset --hard

commit_message:
Remove non-voting job from the swift gate

The gate-swift-tox-func job is non-voting. It currently is a job
in both the check and gate queues on the swift repo.

Non-voting jobs should not be in the gate queue. This patch
removes the non-voting job from the swift gate queue.

commit_message:
Misc Python 3 compatibility fixes

Python 3 renames StringIO -> io.  Use six to deal
with this change.

Introduces new test dependency on six for StringIO.

Change-Id: Ia875b7fcbb976599053970ef79ed3f3474626bad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-testr refs/changes/51/194551/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from six import StringIO self.stdout = StringIO() self.stderr = StringIO()
deleted_lines: import StringIO self.stdout = StringIO.StringIO() self.stderr = StringIO.StringIO()

commit_message:
handle utf8 encoding properly

The previous implementation was causing keystone tests to fail,
we need to correctly check what type of string is being served before
attempting to encode it and service it to the mangler.

Change-Id: I22e6ecbf07b41e486b0735dfea67ec14509b5a95
